# Key Roles and Needs Analysis

**Generated:** 2025-06-06T00:26:13.970Z  
**Description:** Analysis of user roles and their specific needs

---

## HR Insights Dashboard: Key User Roles and Needs

This document outlines the key user roles and their needs for the HR Insights Dashboard project, providing actionable insights for system design and implementation.

**I. Primary User Roles:**

**1. Chief Human Resources Officer (CHRO):**

* **Role Description & Responsibilities:** Oversees all HR functions, sets strategic HR direction, and makes high-level decisions based on data insights.
* **Specific Needs & Requirements:**  High-level overview dashboards, customizable reports, trend analysis, predictive analytics, executive summaries, ability to filter data by department/location/timeframe.  Access to all tabs.
* **Business Processes:** Strategic planning, resource allocation, budget justification, performance review of HR department.
* **Success Criteria:** Improved strategic decision-making, demonstrable ROI from HR initiatives, increased efficiency in HR operations.
* **Pain Points:** Lack of timely and accurate data, difficulty in identifying key trends, insufficient data visualization, inability to benchmark against competitors.
* **Technology & Tool Requirements:**  Interactive dashboards, data visualization tools, reporting and analytics capabilities, secure access control.
* **Communication & Collaboration Needs:** Regular updates on dashboard performance, access to data analysts for ad-hoc requests.
* **Training & Support Requirements:**  High-level training on dashboard functionality and interpretation of key metrics.


**2. HR Business Partners (HRBPs):**

* **Role Description & Responsibilities:**  Work directly with business units to address HR-related needs, provide consultation, and implement HR strategies.
* **Specific Needs & Requirements:**  Data drill-down capabilities, ability to filter data by business unit, access to relevant sections (e.g., Employee Experience, Succession Planning), customized reports for specific business needs. Access to all tabs except perhaps Top HR Trends (unless directly relevant to their business unit).
* **Business Processes:** Performance management, talent acquisition, employee relations, change management, workforce planning.
* **Success Criteria:** Improved employee engagement, increased efficiency in HR operations, better alignment between HR and business strategies.
* **Pain Points:**  Inconsistent data across different HR systems, difficulty in identifying root causes of employee engagement issues, lack of real-time data.
* **Technology & Tool Requirements:**  Interactive dashboards, data filtering and sorting capabilities, report generation tools, mobile access.
* **Communication & Collaboration Needs:**  Regular updates on dashboard improvements, access to support staff for troubleshooting.
* **Training & Support Requirements:**  Training on data interpretation and report generation.


**3. HR Analysts:**

* **Role Description & Responsibilities:**  Collect, analyze, and interpret HR data; create reports and visualizations; support decision-making.
* **Specific Needs & Requirements:**  Advanced data analysis capabilities, data extraction and manipulation tools, ability to create custom reports and visualizations, access to all data sources.  Full access to all tabs.
* **Business Processes:** Data collection, data cleaning, data analysis, report generation, data visualization, presentation of findings.
* **Success Criteria:**  Accurate and timely delivery of data insights, identification of actionable trends, effective communication of findings.
* **Pain Points:**  Data silos, inconsistent data quality, lack of appropriate analytical tools.
* **Technology & Tool Requirements:**  Advanced analytics software, data visualization tools, data mining tools, programming languages (e.g., R, Python).
* **Communication & Collaboration Needs:**  Collaboration with HRBPs and CHRO, access to IT support.
* **Training & Support Requirements:**  Advanced training on data analysis techniques and dashboard functionalities.


**II. Secondary Stakeholder Roles:**

**1. Business Unit Leaders:** Interested in data related to their specific teams (employee engagement, turnover, succession planning).  Access to relevant sections of the dashboard, likely filtered by their unit.

**2. Employees:**  May have access to limited data related to their own performance, benefits, and development opportunities (e.g., via self-service portal).


**III. Administrative and Support Roles:**

**1. HR Data Administrators:** Responsible for data entry, data validation, and data quality management.  Access to data entry and validation tools.

**2. IT Support:**  Provides technical support for the dashboard and underlying systems.


**IV. Technical and Operational Roles:**

**1. Data Engineers:** Responsible for data integration, data warehousing, and data pipeline management.

**2. Software Developers:** Responsible for the development, maintenance, and enhancement of the dashboard.


**V. Decision-Making Roles and Authority Levels:**

CHRO has ultimate decision-making authority on strategic HR initiatives. HRBPs make decisions on tactical HR issues within their business units.


**VI. External Partner and Vendor Roles:**

Potentially external vendors for data analytics tools, dashboard development, and data integration services.


**VII. Regulatory and Compliance Roles:**

HR professionals responsible for ensuring compliance with data privacy regulations (e.g., GDPR, CCPA).  Data access control and audit trails are crucial.


**VIII. End-user and Customer Roles:**  Employees are end-users, while business unit leaders are considered customers of the HR department's services.


This detailed breakdown provides a solid foundation for designing and implementing the HR Insights Dashboard, addressing the needs of all key user roles and ensuring its success.  Further refinement will be necessary through stakeholder interviews and workshops.
